title: Approved Cleaners Chemicals
content: Approved Cleaners Chemicals Approved Cleaners & Chemicals ONLY ONE CHEMICAL AT A TIME - DO NOT MIX CHEMICALS! Enclosures: Walls: 256 Windows: Windex Floors: Odoban or Bleach Windows (both pet care and office areas): Windex Windows when extra cleaning: Sprayway Play Gyms/Play Yards: 256 Floors (both pet care and office areas): Odoban or Bleach Desks/Surface Cleaner: 256 - MUST BE IN SPRAY BOTTLE ONLY, or Windex Washing dishes manually: Palmolive Dishwasher (not washing manually) Rinse Additive: "TMA - Premier Rinse Additive" Detergent: "All Temp Detergent Extra," Product Code SO 5820 ONLY ONE CHEMICAL AT A TIME - DO NOT MIX CHEMICALS! DO NOT MIX OR PREPARE CHEMICALS NEARBY ANIMALS. If you think a pet may have ingested a potentially poisonous substance, call the ASPCA Animal Poison Control Hotline at (888) 426-4435. A consultation fee may apply. THE CHEMICALS LISTED ARE PERMITTED FOR USE ONLY FOR THE LISTED USE CASES. NO OTHER CHEMICAL CAN BE USED UNLESS MANAGEMENT OR OWNER'S PERMISSION IS OBTAINED.

title: Handling Stool
content: Handling Stool Handling Stool Operating Procedure Picking up stool Stool must be picked up and disposed of immediately . Even if the poop is not from the pet you were walking, it is imperative to remove the feces ASAP. Poop must be disposed in one of the garbage-bag-lined galvanized can with a tight fitting lid. The lid MUST remain on the can at all times to prevent dogs and flies from accessing it. Stool can contain viruses, bacteria, parasites, diseases like Giardia, and more. Rememeber, saftey first! Any abnormal stool (blood, diarrhea, loose, mucus, and stool with foreign bodies in it) should be brought to the attention of a manager immediately. There should always be one poop scoop set, a bucket, and steel can per fenced-in area. If any poop scoops need to be replaced, please let a manager know. Please see "Cleaning Up Diarrhea and/or Vomit" Precedure if a pet makes a mess in their room.

title: Washing Dishes
content: Washing Dishes Washing Dishes Operating Procedure Hand Washing Dishes / Bowls The object is clean, “slime free” bowls as quickly as possible while not wasting water, energy and soap. Start with a clean sink and drying basin. Sanitize the sink with 256 and rinse. Discard any remaining food and stack bowls according to size. Plug the drain to allow water to collect in the wash basin. Do not plug the basin used for drying. Add a splash of soapy water between the bowls to help dissolve solids. Soap the sponge and use hot water with a low flow rate and wash both sides and all surfaces. Leave dish water in the sink for soaking bowls as they are collected. Do not drain the sink until clean bowls are put into the drying basin. After dishes have been washed, rinse with a higher flow rate and place in the second basin to drip dry. Stack in such a way as to ensure they are able to drip dry. Dry with dish towels and stack according to size on the metal cart. Water bowls on the bottom, food bowls on the top shelf according to size. Cat and mini mansion water bowls are stored in the cat room cabinets and on the top of the mini mansions. Using the Dishwasher Visually check the drain cover to make sure there is no food residue. If there is any food residue, take the cover out and clean it before starting the dishwasher. Lightly rinse bowls with water and use a sponge to get any food residue from them before you put them in the dishwasher. Put a few drops of rinse aid in the bottom of the dishwasher each time you use the dishwasher. Run dishwasher cycle When finished, remove the bowls and inspect. If clean, dry and stack in the kitchen. If still dirty, hand wash before stacking in kitchen.

title: Daycare and Boarding Lunches Gourmet Treats
content: Daycare and Boarding Lunches Gourmet Treats Daycare and Boarding Lunches & Gourmet Treats Operating Procedure Boarding Lunches and Gourmet Treats: Boarding lunches and gourmet treats should only be printed and prepared at lunch time, so we have the most up-to-date feeding info. In Gingr, start by accessing the “Feeding Report” under the Reports section. First, only select “Lunch” then select “Show animals without feeding info”, and deselect “Only show animals currently checked in,” to make sure it matches the image below. Also, put the report in room number alphabetical order by clicking “Lodging”! Press “Get PDF,” and print two copies. Highlight the feeds on both copies that will be made in the kitchen. Cut up one copy of the feeds (only the highlighted ones need to be cut) Prepare lunches and sign off once done. Note: if you cannot find a dog's food but they are currently checked in, the food is probably in the hallway, as they are leaving today. Conversely, a dog's lunch might still be in their bag up front, if they recently arrived. Please triple-check to make sure all dogs are fed correctly. Gourmet Treats In Gingr, start by accessing the “Services By Date” report under the Reports section. Under the “Services” section, select any option that has Gold, Silver, and Puppy. Then press “Scheduled Within Date Range.” Don’t forget to put the report in alphabetical order by lodging name by clicking “Lodging”! Print up one copy, and prepare the gourmet treats. How to prepare and deliver gourmet treats: Gourmet treats should be about 1-2 tablespoons per dog. Cats get a few shreds of house chicken as their gourmet treat. Mixed mashed potato mix, frozen vegetables, a small amount of chicken, and water in a large tupperware bowl with a lid. The consistency should be a good balance between not being runny, but not being too thick. Gather clean small bowls and the lunch feeding cart (boarding lunches and gourmet treats should be handed out together) When handing out gourmet treats, put the gourmet treat in the pet's existing food bowl in their room. If there is no pre-existing food bowl, put the gourmet treat in one of the new, small bowls. Lunchtime Medications: While it is rare a pet will need medications administered during lunchtime, it is still important to check the medication during lunchtime every day. On the left hand side menu on Gingr, navigate to 'Reports & More' > 'Reports' > 'Medication Report'. Under 'Medication Schedule', filter by 'Lunch' to see if there are any lunch medications. If there are any lunchtime medications, print up a copy and ensure the medication is administered. Don't forget to sign off once medication is administered. Daycare Lunches: Daycare lunches are typically kept outside of a pet's room in their basket. Check the refrigerator and freezer thoroughly to see if there are any daycare lunches. Check all the daycare bags in the hallway to see if there is any food in them. Sometimes, there will be food that we should not give the pet but the owner packed anyway, so please ask reception if there is any question. Gather a sufficient stack of medium-sized bowls. Walk and feed dogs their lunches in ALL AREAS, starting with Outside East, checking every single room to see if there is food outside their room. On really busy days, there may be daycare dogs in North. Ensure the North dogs are fed lunch. Check underneath room cards and in the dog's bag if they brought one in to ensure all food is given to the pet. If the pet brings in a small bag of treats, give ALL OF THEM to the pet during lunch time - if the pet brings in a big bag, give a reasonable amount. Double check all areas to ensure each and every lunch was given.

title: Place Soiled Bedding in Laundry
content: Place Soiled Bedding in Laundry Place Soiled Bedding in Laundry Operating Procedure Place Dirty Bedding in Laundry IF THE BED OR ITEM IS THE OURS: Retrieve the dirty bed. If it is a Kuranda bed, spray with disinfectant, and let sit for 10 minutes before drying off. If it is really soiled, take it to an area outside to rinse with a foamer and hose to completely deep clean the bed. Then dry off bed and return to room. If it is a soft standard bed, remove all feces from the bed using a poop scoop, (if needed take it outside to rinse off with hose). After all feces from bed is removed, place bed in laundry bin so it can be washed. IF THE BED OR ITEM IS THE CUSTOMER'S: Retrieve the dirty bed. R emove all feces from the bed or item using a poop scoop, (if needed take it outside to rinse off with hose). After all feces is removed, place item in laundry bin so it can be washed. BE SURE TO LOG IT ON THE GUEST LAUNDRY SHEET! Return item back to guest's room as soon as possible. If the pet is leaving today, notify reception that the item is in laundry.

title: Taking and Sending Pictures
content: Taking and Sending Pictures Taking and Sending Pictures Operating Procedure This procedure will ensure great pictures are taken and sent efficiently and accurately. Why are great pictures important? Customers love to receive pictures of their dogs and cats! Pictures are the only glimpse of our clients’ pet stay when they are away, so it is crucially important to take great pictures. Our clients greatly appreciate this, as it reassures them that their pet is doing great staying at PAWS. What can go wrong? If a client receives a picture of their pet that looks dirty, out of focus, and/or the pet looks sad, the pet parents expect the worst. The pet parent may decide not to come back simply because of a picture where their pet looks sad. As mentioned earlier, the photos sent to pet parents are the only glimpse of their pet's stay - please use extra care and patience when taking photos. The importance of taking great pictures cannot be underestimated. Picture Guidelines The staff member must be trained in taking the photographs by a qualified staff member and all pictures must be approved by a supervisor until we are confident the staff member understands what we are looking for. Pictures should only be taken outside in the greenyards or in the play gym (prioritize taking them in the greenyards). Pictures should never be taken on concrete or have poop buckets/shovels, etc (anything that is dirty). People love to see their dogs interact and having fun. The picture should make the owner happy that they entrusted us with the care of their beloved pet. OBJECTIVE: Happy, clean dogs having fun! Be patient. It can take some time and multiple pictures before you get the perfect photo. THE FOLLOWING IS ENCOURAGED: Colorful, fun images. Pets playing with each other (nicely). Dogs smiling and having fun. Get to the pet’s level. Pictures taken from above looking down are not as flattering. For cats, having them engaged and playing (cat tree is great for this!) THE FOLLOWING IS NOT ALLOWED: Slobber. Poop in the background. Poop buckets in the background. Dirty pets. Out-of-focus images. Wet floor in the play gym. Hair or debris in the background. Aggressive looking animals (including pets in the background of photos). Photos on concrete (unless the concrete is 100% clean and there is some sort of green in the picture). 'Live' photos (feature with iPhones). Sad looking pets (have patience - engage with the pet and try to get them to smile!) Photos with poor lighting. Excessive fencing or foreign objects in the background. Photos taken inside of suites. Departure Pictures for Boarding We send at least one picture of each boarding guest the day before departure. This procedure must be started before the first group starts to ensure all photos will be taken. To access the departure picture list: Navigate to 'Reports & More' > 'Reports' > 'Reservations By Day'. Select tomorrow's date. In the 'Reservation Types' section, select only the boarding options. Press 'Generate Report'. Click 'Lodging' to sort by room order. This will generate both a 'Check Ins' and a 'Check Outs' section. To see only departures: "X" out of the 'Check Ins' section. Click 'Lodging' to sort by room order. Then, press 'Print PDF' to print. Highlight all dogs that are in group play. Group leaders are to take photos of group dogs in group play, and pet care technicians will take pictures of the individual play pets during their custom playtimes. All photos must be sent along with the pet's name to the Paws house cell phone number at (203)443-3031 once taken. Pictures can ONLY be sent to the pet parent with supervisor approval. Daycare pictures We always send pictures for a dog's first day of daycare. These are to be sent mid-day, along with a mid-day call to the pet parent to inform them about how their dog is doing. We like to send pictures to existing daycare pet parents, too! If you get a cute picture of a pet while they are in daycare, don't hesitate to send it to the pet parent! Reminder, only send pictures if you are authorized to do so. Social Media Posts We post to Facebook and Instagram on an almost daily basis. When posting to social media, please only select the best photos from the day. For Facebook, it should be around 10-15 photos, and on Instagram, 3-5 photos is a good range. If there are more wonderful photos taken, don't hesitate to post more pictures than these recommendations - but still remember to only post the best photos out of the bunch. Do not post a photo in which you can read a dog's ID collar, as we want to maintain all pet's anonymity online for safety. Please use fun but appropriate captions - some good ideas include the day of the week (ie: "Sunday Funday!

title: Creating an Incident Report
content: Creating an Incident Report Creating an Incident Report This procedure is designed to ensure that comprehensive notes are recorded and communicated in all situations / occurrences where a dog is observed to display any "abnormal" or concerning behavior or condition while in the care of Paws Pet Resort. Pet Care staff are trained to know what to look for and what constitutes "abnormal" behavior. WHEN IN DOUBT, CREATE A NOTE IN THE PET'S FILE AND LET A MANAGER OR SUPERVISOR KNOW ABOUT THE BEHAVIOR. If the issue is serious and/or if there is an injury involved, create a new Incident Report for an animal: Navigate to the pet's profile on Gingr. Then navigate to the Incidents section on the animal's profile. Complete all required fields on the new Incident Report on Gingr. The more information the better! Save Write notes in the file and tell management!

title: Dilution of Cleaning Solutions
content: Dilution of Cleaning Solutions Dilution of Cleaning Solutions Operating Procedure Dilution of Cleaning Solutions S.O.P Odoban is used in mop buckets for cleaning luxury suites, floors in hallways, kitchen and laundry room. Add a half cup of Odoban for each gallon of water. A typical mop bucket holds 3 gallons of water so you would add 1.5 cups of Odoban. Bleach can also be used in mop buckets for cleaning luxury suites, floors, etc but this should only be used as the last cleaning of the night. The bleach dilution for mop buckets is the same as Odoban. Petedge 256 is used in mop buckets for the play gym only. Add ½ tablespoon for each gallon of water. When using the pump dispenser, 4 pumps = 1 tablespoon so you would need 6 pumps (1 ½ tablespoons) to 3 gallons of water. Petedge 256 is used in spray bottles for cleaning walls, doors, cat condos, minis, etc. Add 1 tablespoon (1/2 oz) of 256 to a full gallon (128 oz) of water for a 1:256 dilution. Mix solution in a gallon jug before filling spray bottles to ensure proper dilution. Add water first then 256 to prevent foaming. Petedge 256 is used in the hydrofoamers at full strength. The gray tip located in the dispenser mixes the 256 with water to the proper dilution. Cat bucket for litter scoops-and poop buckets should be filled with 2 gallons of water and add 2 tablespoons (or 8 pumps) of 256 from the concentrated gallon. Dirty litter boxes should be filled halfway with water and add 1 pump of 256 from the concentrated gallon. All chemicals and cleaning supplies must be kept in the laundry room and away from the pets in our care-including foamers. CAUTION! Cleaning products should NEVER be mixed! Cleaning products should NEVER be mixed around or near dogs ! Notify a member of management immediately if a pet comes in contact with or ingests any of our cleaners and then contact poison control. If you think a pet may have ingested a potentially poisonous substance, call the ASPCA Animal Poison Control Hotline at (888) 426-4435. A consultation fee may apply. Revised 6/3/24 by CR & RW

title: Completing Laundry
content: Completing Laundry Completing Laundry Operating Procedure The laundry should start in the morning continuously until it is all done. It only takes a few minutes to put the towels/bedding in, fold the things in the dryer, switch over the loads, and fill the washer. Guest bedding will be logged in with suite #, dog’s name, item description, and date. Shake out laundry before loading it into the machine (you’d be surprised at what you find!) If the bedding is really dirty, put it outside and hose it off. If a little dirty rinse in the small laundry room sink before adding to laundry. Loosely fill the washer 3/4 full. Do not overload. Sprinkle ~1/4 cup of dry detergent for a full load, less for smaller loads on top of laundry. Select appropriate load size. Water temp = cool Cycle = normal/regular When the wash cycle is complete, shake out the items before placing them in the dryer. If items are still very wet, rearrange the items and run the “drain spin” cycle again. Do not put sopping wet items in the dryer. Mop heads do not go in the dryer. Hang them to air dry. Clean lint trap with every load When the dryer is complete, fold the laundry and put away. All bedding and cleaning rags are folded with like edges lined up and stored on wire racks by size, color and type. Grooming towels are folded and stored in the grooming room. Luxury fleeces are folded then rolled so they can fit into the cubbies neatly without any raw edges showing. Extra luxury fleece can be placed rolled up on top of the cubbies. Put away the folded laundry. Don’t leave it on the windowsill. If the house bedding has a lot of holes please throw it out. If it only has a few we may be able to cut it and reuse it- place it in the designated spot in the laundry room above the sink. Return guest bedding to their suites. Check off the guest laundry log. If we will not be returning guest bedding to the suite, label it with the name, suite number, dates of stay and reason why it is not to be returned. Store it in the kitchen near the food bag with the label facing out. The laundry should be done continuously throughout the day. Laundry should not be left for the p.m. shift and never left overnight unless there are not enough items to start a new load. Make sure the laundry room is neat and tidy and tour ready at all times. Wipe down all surfaces, including the sides and doors of the washing machine and dryer. Sweep and mop as needed. All mop buckets will be emptied at the end of each shift (with exceptions if the bucket is new). Cat scoops and litter boxes will be cleaned and put away before the end of each shift. At the end of the day the room will be thoroughly swept and mopped being sure to get under and behind mop buckets, brooms, etc. All surfaces will be wiped down and disinfected with 256.

title: Performing a Wellness Check
content: Performing a Wellness Check Performing a Wellness Check Opertating Procedure 5-Point Wellness Check: A wellness check will be performed with every walk and rotation. The 5 Points of a Wellness Check: Eyes Observe the guest’s eyes. They should be clear and bright, full of life. Eyes that appear dull and lifeless could be a sign of “trouble brewing.” Dull eyes could also be a sign of anxiety and stress. Check to see if there is any discharge, swelling, opacities or ulcerations (sores). Pay particular attention to pugs, Pekingese, Lhasas and Persian breeds that have protruding eyes and are prone to eye difficulties. Teeth Place hand on top of the bridge of the guest’s nose and the other under the mandible (underside of snout). Gently part the lips with your fingers to expose the teeth and gums. Look for any broken, missing or stained teeth, any gum conditions, excessive tarter and noticeably unpleasant odors. Ears Stand beside the guest, taking one hand to lift the flap of the ear. Observe how the dog reacts to having ears touched. Shying away or fear may be a sign of ear pain or chronic problems. Bend the ear back slightly, and use your other hand to spread apart the cartilage part of the ear. Check the ear canal for any discharge, inflammation, dirt or excessive amounts of wax or hair growth. A healthy ear will appear light pink and have no odor. Repeat the above steps on the other side of the guest to check the opposite ear. Skin and Coat With your fingers, life the hair against the direction of the coat growth, looking for abrasions, skin irritations, dry skin, growths or other abnormal conditions. Does the coat appear healthy and shiny, or dull and lifeless? Look for any urine burns or stains, or fecal matter attached to the coat. Check for any matted areas, as they often conceal sores or parasites. Check the coat in all areas, including under the jaw, behind the ears, neck, elbows, chest, stomach, inside rear legs and hocks, and above and below the tail. Legs, Paws, and Genitals Male guests - Check the scrotum for any signs of irritation, abnormal growth, swelling or excessive warmth. Check the penis for any signs of unusual discharge (occasional, slightly greenish discharge is considered normal). Female guests - Check the vulva for any signs of enlargement or discharge. Check the mammary glands for any lumps or swelling. Pay particular attention to signs of estrus (heat) in an unaltered female. All guests, male and female - Check the anal area for evidence of tapeworm segments, anal gland swelling or other irritations. Additional items to assess: Assess the dog’s demeanor. Do they seem alert and responsive, or listless or lethargic? Check for any signs of bloat (see symptoms below). Bloat is a very serious health risk for dogs. Bloating of a dog’s stomach is usually related to swallowed air (although food and fluid can be present). It usually happens when there is an abnormal accumulation of air, fluid, and/or foam in the stomach. Stress can be a significant contributing factor as well. As the stomach swells, it can rotate, causing the fixed attachments between the esophagus and upper intestine to twist. The twisting stomach traps air, food, and water in the stomach. The bloated stomach obstructs veins in the abdomen, leading to low blood pressure, shock, and damage to internal organs. This combined effect can lead to the death of a dog. Most common symptoms of bloat: Attempts to vomit unsuccessfully, every 5-30 minutes. This is one of the most common signs. Frequently “asking” to go outside to eliminate, significantly more often than normal Significant anxiety or restlessness “Hunched Up” or “Roached Up” appearance Bloated abdomen that feels tight (like a drum) IF YOU OBSERVE AND POTENTIAL SIGNS OF BLOAT, IMMEDIATELY NOTIFY THE SHIFT SUPERVISOR, WELLNESS MANAGER, OR LOCATION MANAGER.

title: Preparing Suites for Arrivals
content: Preparing Suites for Arrivals Preparing Suites for Arrivals Operating Procedure Cats: Check the occupied runs list to see who is arriving. Prepare rooms scheduled for arrivals with water, bedding and a litter box. ALL DOG SUITES: The receptionist or whoever brings the dog back is responsible for providing the pet with a fresh, clean water bowl. No other prep work must be done ahead of time besides the daily obvious suite cleaning that is already completed. Pet techs will hand out bedding after the dog has arrived - besides Luxury Suites, where the bedding is already in place when the dog arrives. Luxury Suites: A Kuranda bed will already be in the suite as part of the cleaning procedure, and upon arrival it is the receptionist or whoever brings the dog back to the room's responsibility to ensure the bed is of the correct size.

title: Departure Assessment
content: Departure Assessment Departure Assessment Operating Procedure This important procedure is designed to ensure each Guest that is departing is clean, free of odor, has been bathed (if scheduled) and is ready to go home. If a dog or cat comes home dirty and smelly, the client will assume the worst. This procedure is done on the day the pet is departing. Departure Assessment Time: Starts as soon as 5:30AM, MUST be complete by 7:00AM. Obtain a grooming brush. Print out today's departure list for all overnight guests (dogs and cats!) Proceed to each Guest, enter the Suite and check the following: Does the Guest look clean? Check the pet head-to-tail for visual signs of dirt, feces, etc. Use the grooming brush to brush/smooth the pet's coat if necessary. MAKE SURE THE PET DOES NOT SMELL BAD. If a pet does smell bad, immediately bring them to grooming for a no-charge quick bath/cleanup. Complete this before the doors open! Return guest to room once and if no-charge quick bath is completed.

title: Social Media Posts
content: Social Media Posts Social Media Posts Operating Procedure We post to Facebook and Instagram on an almost daily basis. When posting to social media, please only select the best photos from the day. For Facebook, it should be around 10-15 photos, and on Instagram, 3-5 photos is a good range. If there are more wonderful photos taken, don't hesitate to post more pictures than these recommendations - but still remember to only post the best photos out of the bunch. Do not post a photo in which you can read a dog's ID collar, as we want to maintain all pet's anonymity online for safety. Please use fun but appropriate captions - some good ideas include the day of the week (ie: "Sunday Funday!) or national days relating to dogs (ie: National Pet Day, etc).

title: Cleaning Up Diarrhea andor Vomit
content: Cleaning Up Diarrhea andor Vomit Cleaning Up Diarrhea and/or Vomit Operating Procedure This procedure is designed to ensure that "messes" are cleaned up in a timely manner and in manner that effectively disinfects and kills any parasites that may have been contained Guest's diarrhea or vomit. If the "mess" is small, Retrieve the cleaning cart. Verify that the cart is stocked with: 5-10 clean/unused cleaning towels Latex gloves Handheld spray bottle of disinfectant Deck squeegee Proceed to the Soiled Room Escort the guest to a temporary holding area. Bring dog to grooming room if the dog needs a clean-up bath, make sure to check the dog head to tail and smell them! Place gloves on your hands. Use towels to remove the feces/vomit. You can use disinfectant from the handheld spray bottle to dilute if necessary. If solid feces needs to be removed, use a poop scooper to remove and discard into an "poop bucket". Spray the area with disinfectant. After the disinfectant has been sitting on the area for 10 minutes , Thoroughly dry the area with a towel. Place the Guest back into the room. Make sure door to the room is securely shut. If the "mess" is significant EAST, WEST, IN-BETWEEN, OR OUTSIDE WEST: Proceed to the Soiled Room Escort the guest to a temporary holding area. Bring dog to grooming room if the dog needs a clean-up bath, make sure to check the dog head to tail and smell them! Remove all beds, bowls, toys, etc., from the floor. (all customer belongings should be labeled so they go back to the correct dog. If it is not labeled, please do so.) If anything is dirty, wet, or smelly; bring it to the laundry room (make sure to log any customer belongings on the guest laundry sheet). All items must be returned to the customer clean. Scoop any spilled food or solid waste. You must mark the run card for any elimination in their room and record food and water intake. Foam the floor, then walls, doors, floors and resting bench. Be sure to do the panel next to the door and the base of the bars and let sit for 10 minutes. Rinse the walls first, top to bottom, rinse floor from front to back, top of resting bench, flip up and rinse bottom of resting bench. While rinsing, have the hose in one hand and a scrub brush in the other to tackle any remaining grime. Lastly, flush the drain towards the drain bucket until clean. Leave benches up to allow them to drip dry until you are done. Squeegee the doors; two swipes from top to bottom Squeegee the bedroom from front to back, two swipes and gently put down the bench. Put down clean water bowl If the dog had belongings, put those back in with them now (give out our beds as needed to non chewers only). Bring the dog back into their room and securely shut the door. NORTH, LUXURIES, MINIS, CAT ROOMS: Retrieve the cleaning cart. Verify that the cart is stocked with: 5-10 clean/unused cleaning towels Latex gloves Handheld spray bottle of disinfectant Proceed to the Soiled Room Escort the guest to a temporary holding area. Bring dog to grooming room if the dog needs a clean-up bath, make sure to check the dog head to tail and smell them! Place gloves on your hands. Use towels to remove the feces/vomit. You can use disinfectant from the handheld spray bottle to dilute if necessary. If solid feces needs to be removed, use a poop scooper to remove and discard into an "poop bucket". Spray the area with disinfectant. After the disinfectant has been sitting on the area for 10 minutes , Thoroughly dry the area with a towel. Place the Guest back into the room. Make sure door to the room is securely shut.

title: Required Vaccinations Policy
content: Required Vaccinations Policy Required Vaccinations Internal Policy The following internal policies are designed to help ensure that all guests of Paws Pet Resort & Spa are healthy. REQUIRED - Must be current to visit Paws Pet Resort & Spa for ANY service. DOGS CATS Rabies Rabies Distemper Feline Distemper Bordetella Negative Fecal Within Past 12 Months Current Dog Town License (Paper Copy) DETAILS: Dogs: Rabies - in most states, the Rabies vaccines are required to be given to dogs over 3-4 months of age and every 3 years. Rabies vaccines are given to protect people, not dogs. Because rabies is typically a fatal disease after the onset of symptoms, the goal is to protect the public from contracting rabies. DHLP is a five-way vaccine that includes viral diseases canine distemper, hepatitis, parvovirus, and bacterial infection leptospirosis. Distemper is an airborne virus that is also transmitted through bodily fluids and attacks the intestinal and respiratory tracts, as well as the central nervous system. Bordetella - The bordetella vaccine is given to both puppies and adult dogs. This vaccine helps to ward off a frequent illness that is known as canine cough. Canine cough is easily spread from one dog to another and is highly contagious. In healthy adult dogs, the condition is similar to common cold in humans. NOTE: The bordetella vaccine should be delivered not less than 3 days prior to arrival. A Paws Pet Resort Owner or Manager MUST approve the acceptance of dog receiving a "last minute" bordetella vaccine.' Negative fecal test within past 12 months : We require at least an Ova & Parasite test (OP), and prefer an Ova, Parasite, and Giardia (OPG) test. Please refer to the fecal results sheet for more information. Current Dog Town License (paper copy): Required by Connecticut state law. If their primary residence is not located in Connecticut, we or the customer must provide proof that the area they live in does not mandate a dog license. An example can be a state website that says this, or verbal confirmation by a town clerk. Note: Rabies and Dog Town License must be uploaded to client's file on Gingr. RECOMMENDED Canine Influenza causes mild respiratory disease and is associated with outbreaks in densely housed dogs or those with frequent connections to other dogs. The vaccination for both common strains is recommended. H3N2 H3N8 Cats: Rabies - Rabies vaccines are given to protect people, not cats. Because rabies is typically a fatal disease after the onset of symptoms, the goal is to protect the public from contracting rabies. Feline Distemper Combo (FVRCP) - three-way vaccine, is an important core vaccine that all cats should be must up to date on. It's made up of three separate vaccinations, FVR (Feline Viral Rhinotracheitis), Calici, and Panleukopenia. Clients should email all paperwork to: info@pawspet.com

title: Pull Luggage for Departing Guests aka Appointment Notes
content: Pull Luggage for Departing Guests aka Appointment Notes Pull Luggage for Departing Guests a.k.a. Appointment Notes Operating Procedure This procedure is designed to ensure that all luggage and food from home is returned to the Guest's Pet Parents upon departure. Log into Gingr from a desktop computer. Navigate to " Reports" > "Check Outs" Set the date to tomorrow and set the class filter to select ONLY THE BOARDING OPTIONS. Click the top of the "Lodging" column header to quickly sort Guests by room number. Print the list. Collect Items Starting with the top of the list, working one pet at a time, check off each individual item they brought in as soon as you find it and it is in their bag. You may need to gather any luggage that is present in the pet's room. This includes toys, treats, blankets, EVERYTHING they brought in! Check to make sure any bedding or any belongings are not soiled or wet and that it does not smell foul or have excessive hair on it. Immediately inform the shift supervisor and take it to the laundry if it does. (Don't forget to log it on the guest laundry sheet!) Make sure to keep all items together for each guest, especially if they have multiple bags. Once all items are collected and signed off on, sign your initials on the left of the pet's name. There should be nothing missing. Proceed to the kitchen hallway with the luggage. DO NOT PUT ANY PERISHABLE FOOD ITEMS IN HALLWAY! If any belongings, food, etc, is in the refridgerator or freezer, put a sticky note on their other bag in the hallway. Example " Murphy has bag of Freshpet in fridge ". If they don't have another bag, attach the note to the luggage sheet that will be in the hallway. This will ensure reception will know to give all belongings back. ENSURE ALL ITEMS ARE FOUND, IF ANYTHING IS MISSING, TELL A MANAGER AND ENSURE IT IS FOUND BEFORE THE DAY ENDS! Once all items are in the hallway, place the corresponding report cards in each bag. Carefully read and use caution! Tape the signed off departure luggage sheet on the wall in the kitchen hall, where all the guest's belongings are. No toys, treats, or ANY other belongings should be in or near the departing pet's room at this point!

title: Completing Eliminations and Walks
content: Completing Eliminations and Walks Completing Eliminations and Walks Operating Procedure All canine guests will receive "Eliminations" each day to ensure they have a sufficient opportunity to urinate and defecate outside, just like they do at home. This procedure is designed to ensure this service is completed in a safe, friendly, and efficient manner. Eliminations: can be either during playtime, or a walk. This procedure will ensure each dog is out at least 4 times per day. Important Notes: Never leave gates or dog's room doors open Clean rooms if needed If a dog needs to be cleaned, bring them into grooming for a no-charge, quick bath. Eliminations will be started 30 MINUTES after the dogs have been fed. Times Outside Chart East, In Between, West, Outside West, North: Luxury Suites, Mini Mansions: First Time Out Done during AM cleaning Done during AM cleaning Second Time Out WALK: Started AFTER first group goes out, ~9:00AM. PLAYTIME: individual or group plays must be started by 10:30AM. Third Time Out PLAYTIME: individual or group plays must be started between 11:00AM to 1:30PM. WALK: starts at 11:00AM, ends at 1:30PM. Fourth Time Out WALK: starts at 4:30PM, 30 minutes after PM feeds are handed out. WALK: starts at 4:30PM, 30 minutes after PM feeds are handed out. WALKING PROCEDURE Proceed to lodging guest room. If a dog is showing signs of aggression or anxiety, please ask for a supervisor to help. Safety is #1 priority! Open the door to the room and place a lead around the guest’s neck. Exit the room, making sure the door is securely shut. When walking the dog, keep the leash short, and high up on the dog's neck to maintain control, as presented in PackPro. Walk the guest to the door to get outside. If guest is in Luxuries, Minis, or North, let them off leash in one of our secure play yards - only one dog per yard! Ensure all gates are securely shut. If guest is in East or West, you MUST keep dog on leash at all times when walking them. DO NOT LET DOGS INTERACT WITH EACH OTHER WHEN ON LEASH! Give the dog approximately 3-5 minutes to do their “business.” Clean up and dispose of any feces as soon as you see it. Bring dog back to their room (or other designated area, if cleaning) Remove the lead and close the door, making sure the room door is securely shut. After the walk, remove the empty food bowl - leave the food bowl if they haven't finished. Refill/Top off the water bowl as needed. Sign off on run card (See wellness check SOP for more about wellness checks).

title: Sanitize Outdoor Areas
content: Sanitize Outdoor Areas Sanitize Outdoor Areas Operating Procedure Cleaning the Yards after Sessions: Sanitize with 256 both indoors & all outside yards – This should be done every day. Patios with concrete should not be cleaned during freezing temps. Empty the poop buckets from the play gym or greenyard and empty and refill scoop water buckets with foamer. Windex windows and clean off window sills and any surface that may collect dust or dirt. Clean out the gym drain bucket Monday & Thursday (twice per week).

title: Serving Food and Medications to Guests and Refilling Water
content: Serving Food and Medications to Guests and Refilling Water Serving Food and Medications to Guests and Refilling Water Operating Procedure This procedure is designed to ensure that Guests are fed and meds are handed out per the exact instructions provided by the Pet Parent and constantly have access to fresh and clean water. Meal Schedule: AM MEAL LUNCH PM MEAL 8:30AM 11:30AM 4:00PM Obtain the appropriate feeding cart (AM, Lunch, PM) - make sure it is ready to go out! Proceed to each guest’s room (in logical order, starting with East). READ THE TAG FOR THE ROOM NUMBER, NAME, AND BREED , to ensure the food bowl is being delivered to the right guest. Enter the Guest's room and place the food on the ground. Remove any old food bowl from their room. Exit and ensure the door is shut and secure. If water is low or empty, re-fill with clean water. If there is hair or debris in the water, dump old water into the floor drain before re-filling. Once all the bowls are delivered, wipe off the cart and return it back to the kitchen, put any dirty bowls in the sink to be cleaned, and throw out all the feeding tags. When you are done, walk around to be sure everyone is fed. If they do not have food, check their room card to confirm that they shouldn’t have food, as some dogs are fed only once a day. Medications If no special instructions are given, meds are delivered with the feeds. Confirm that the guest’s name on the room card matches the name and room number on the Medications Report. IF THERE ARE TWO DOGS IN THE ROOM, double-check the pet ID collars to make sure you are delivering the medications to the correct dog, especially if the dogs are the same breed. Try different methods of giving meds (pill pockets, chicken, pb). Watch for allergies! Ask for help if needed. MAKE SURE THE PET HAS EATEN THE MEDICATION! Sign off AFTER you are SURE medication has been consumed and/or administered. Multiple pets in the same room If two or more dogs are in a room but do not have to be separated, place bowls in separate corners, do not place them side by side. Sometimes, it is noted on the feeding tag that the dogs must be seperated to feed, otherwise one dog will eat both meals. In this case, put the dog in a separate room, let them finish their meals, and BE SURE TO RETURN THE MOVED DOG BACK TO THE ORIGINAL ROOM.

title: Looking Tour Ready
content: Looking Tour Ready Looking "Tour Ready" Operating Procedure Our goal is to look our very best at all times. We never know when a customer/potential customer will stop in for a visit/tour. We must put our best foot forward at all times and be sure to keep our facility clean and ‘tour ready’. Exterior Make sure all debris in parking lot and in front of the building is picked up. Water the plants, pull weeds, sweep outside entrance. Vestibule Sweep, mop, dust as needed. Wash windows/doors; make sure they are fingerprint/debris free. Replace any old/damaged signs on windows/bulletin board. Lobby Counters should be cleaned and organized; nothing laying around on floor or anywhere in eyes view. Doors, walls and furniture should be clean at all times. Sweep and mop throughout the day as needed. Make sure all retail shelves/walls are dusted and organized; replenish as needed. Grooming Grooming Room should be as neat and tidy as possible during working hours. Laundry Room Floors should be swept and mopped as needed. Sinks clean and dirt and food free. Window sill empty and dusted; window washed. Bedding should be neat and organized by size. Pet items brought back to rooms when cleaned. Dishes should be cleaned and dried promptly. (refer to SOP on dishwashing) Kitchen Sink, stove and counters should be clean and organized and free of dishes/food/papers. Swept and mopped as needed throughout the day. Food carts wiped down after each use. Outside Greens Clear of poop - must be picked up immediately; clear of pet toys, leaves and debris. Free of bottles/cleaning supplies. Poop buckets are emptied daily; more if needed. Walls, fencing, doors, windows cleaned; misc. toys picked up. East/West Make sure they are cleaned every day, clear of cleaning supplies, clutter, water jugs out of view. Empty baskets with bags, garbage, etc. Outside runs clean/organize as needed. Refer to East/West SOP. Cat Room Make sure departure rooms are cleaned asap. Make sure no food, bags or garbage on counters/floors; everything clean and clear. Sweep/vacuum cat tree. Sweep/mop the floor as needed. Refer to cat room SOP. Bathrooms Clean both bathrooms daily and throughout the day as needed. Wash toilets, sink, mirrors, paper towel holder, etc. Wash walls as needed. Sweep/mop floors daily or as needed. Empty trash daily. Make sure toilet paper/paper towels are full. Refer to bathroom cleaning SOP. Luxury Hallways Make sure all departure rooms are cleaned during shift. There should be a kuranda bed with proper bedding in every room. Make sure all rooms have bowls. Hallways should be clear and free of debris. Sweep/mop throughout the day as needed. Refer to Luxury SOP. Mini Mansions Make sure all departure rooms are cleaned during shift No debris on floor or on top of mini mansions Floors should be swept and mopped and as needed Windows/doors should be clean and hair free Walls/trim wiped down as needed Refer to Mini Mansion SOP.

title: Bedtime Story Tuckin
content: Bedtime Story Tuckin Bedtime Story Tuck-in Operating Procedure The bedtime story tuck-ins are started before the nightly Lock-Up and should take 3-5 minutes each. This is exclusively included in the Gold package for our overnight guests. Grab a children’s book. Sit with the pet and read the book. Pet the dog or cat, straighten the bedding, top the water, say goodnight. Please conduct a quick wellness check to assure the pet is healthy and happy before sleep. Sign off on the play list after you do it with the time completed.

title: Guest Restrictions
content: Guest Restrictions Guest Restrictions - Age, Health, & Behavior Internal Policies The following internal policies are designed to ensure the following: All guests of Paws Pet Resort have minimal risk of harming a human or another dog. All guests of Paws Pet Resort have minimal risk of experiencing a significant health issue during their stay. All guests of Paws Pet Resort can be safely handled by ALL team members during their stay. Age If a dog is over 10 years of age, please ensure the dog is in good health before they visit our facility. Our goal is to make sure we do what is in the pet's best interest! Health Restrictions A pet that has ongoing health issues may not be allowed to visit Paws Pet Resort and Spa. We do not take pets with: Diabetes/Insulin Requires injections Heart issues Kidney issues Skin issues Skeletal issues Cancer FIV (cats) Requires diapers If there are any questions relating to health issues, please ask a manager or owner. If we must turn away a customer for any health issues, please refer them to their veterinarian for medical boarding. Behavior Restrictions: A pet that has ongoing behavior challenges is NOT ALLOWED to visit Paws Pet Resort and Spa. We do not take pets that are: Aggresive Dominant Highly Unpredictable

title: Preparing AM PM Feeds
content: Preparing AM PM Feeds Preparing AM & PM Feeds Operating Procedure PRINTING AM & PM FEEDS Following these critical steps will ensure each pet gets fed accurately. In Gingr, start by accessing the “Feeding Report” under the Reports section. Select “Show animals without feeding info”, and deselect “Only show animals currently checked in,” to make sure it matches the image below. Next, select “Lodging”, to ensure the rooms show in alphabetical order. Then, make sure every animal has at least one “feeding box” on the right hand side. Most, if not all animals will have at least one feeding box, which means they will show up once we print the feeding report. If an animal does not have a box, this means the animal will not show up on the feeding report once you go to print it. To fix an animal that does not have feeding info, open the animal’s name in a new tab, and hit the pencil, then click on the animal's name as shown below. Then, scroll down on the animal profile until you come across the feeding schedule section. Occasionally, there will be notes at the bottom of the feeding schedule which we will add to the AM, Lunch, PM, or appropriate slot depending on what the feeding notes say. Most of the time, however, there will not be feeding notes. In this case, just type “1 Bag Own Food” under the AM and PM slots, since this is the most common feeding schedule (if the owner specifies different feeding instructions at dropoff, we can change them accordingly). The point of adding the standard “1.00 Bag Own Food” is so that the animal will show up when we go to print the report. See example below: Now, press save at the bottom of the animal profile to save, and close out of that tab. Return back to the feeding report tab, and scroll down to ensure every animal has at least one feeding box. Once you have added information to every animal that needs it, refresh the page to ensure each and every animal has at least one feeding box. Great! Now we are prepared to print out feeds. Once again, ensure the correct boxes are selected, and press the lodging button to ensure the report is in alphabetical order by lodging name. Then select only the PM report for today's date, and press “Get PDF” - print two copies. After this, change the date on top to tomorrow's date. Then select AM. Print two copies. Highlight any instructions that include wet food, which will be spice ups. Then, staple one PM feeding report together, and cut up the other copy where the lines are - do the same for AM feeding report. To print lunches, see “How-To: Lunches and Gourmet Treats” MAKING AM & PM FEEDS Important notes: On a pet's first day, by default we do not serve them their AM meal , unless the customer asks us to. It is reception's duty to ask if their pet has been fed today, and to either notify the person making feeds to prepare the AM meal, or for the receptionist to simply make the feeds and give them to the pet. By default, we do not make/give the PM meal for departures, unless desired by the customer and a feeding note is made. For the feeds you highlighted, these are known as spice ups (anything that has wet food or cannot sit out for hours). Put AM "spice ups" on the named shelf on the right of where feeds are prepared, and PM spice ups on the counter in between the refrigerator and the oven. On each feeding cart, allocate each bowl to each corresponding shelf on the cart: TOP SHELF: East, In-Between. MIDDLE SHELF: West, Outside West. BOTTOM SHELF: Luxuries, Minis, and Cats. - Note that North food bowls have their own designated AM/PM feeding cart, and are made in the North kitchen, not in the main building. It is recommended to use a tablet or a phone while making feeds to quickly see if a pet is checked in, leaving, or arriving. Navigate to www.pawspet.gingrapp.com on a mobile device and use your login details. We make AM and PM feeds at the same time. Use the PM cart for PM feeds, and AM cart to hold the AM feeds. The AM and PM feeding list and tags should be side by side when making feeds. When making feeds, you must pull one bag off the shelf at a time. After you are done with one bag, you MUST take the NEXT bag off the shelf. This ensures all bags are handled and adds another level of safety to ensure every pet gets fed. When you are making feeds and the pet's name is on the list, but the bag is not on the shelf, this can mean: The pet has not arrived yet The pet has left, or is leaving today and the bag is in the hallway. If the pet has not arrived yet: Check the "Expected Today" section on the dashboard of Gingr to see if they are coming in today. If they are scheduled to arrive today, tape their AM and/or PM tags on the shelf next to where you make feeds. This will notify team members that the animal's feeds still need to be made. If they are not scheduled to arrive today and are not checked in, throw the tag away. If the pet has left, or is leaving today: If you have confirmed using Gingr the pet has left, throw out their feeding tags. If the pet is leaving today, our protocol is to not make the PM feed *unless wanted and it is notated in feeding notes*. Follow the feeding instructions listed on the tags carefully until all bags have been handled. If you are making feeds and find any feeding information doesn't match up, notify reception or management. If there are any pets that have run out of food, you MUST notify reception or management so we can call the client and have them decide what to feed their pet(s). NEVER ASSUME A PET HAS NO ALLERGIES, AND/OR GIVE THEM HOUSE FOOD OR TREATS WITHOUT OWNER'S PERMISSION!

title: Filling Out Room Cards
content: Filling Out Room Cards Filling out Room Cards Operating Procedure This is what the bottom of a room card looks like. There are four sections per day, one for each elimination. Fill out all the empty squares, as shown with the blue text below. The explanation of the numbers "code" is at the bottom of the run card in case you need a reminder of what each number represents. If anything is abnormal, please write the abnormality on the pet's room card, let management know, and ensure a note is left on the animal's profile in Gingr. This includes: Diahreia Constipation Blood in stool or urine Worms in stool A pet that doesn't pass their wellness check Not drinking enough water or eating enough food Drinking excessive water Throwing up A pet is not acting like normal IF YOU SEE SOMETHING, SAY SOMETHING!

title: Group Play Restrictions
content: Group Play Restrictions Group Play Restrictions Internal Policies The following internal policies are designed to ensure the following: All guests of Paws Pet Resort that participate in Group Play have minimal risk of harming another dog. All guests of Paws Pet Resort that participate in Group Play have minimal risk of harming a staff member. Mature Intact male (un-neutured) and female (un-spayed) dogs do not have an opportunity to interact with other dogs. Evaluations If an owner wants their dog to play with other dogs, new dogs must be evaluated during their first visit to Paws Pet Resort to ensure they are suitable for group activities. AFTER the dog has been evaluated, their animal profile MUST be updated in Gingr. Assign the Small, Medium, Big, or Individal play icon to the animal's account. Add notes of play style and temperament in the animal notes section in Gingr after evaluation is completed. The First Time checklist must be completed for every single dog's first day. Click here to view the checklist. Puppies Any puppy that is under 6 months is recommended for our puppy program. ANY DOG OVER 8 MONTHS AND NOT FIXED CANNOT PLAY WITH OTHER DOGS! Intact male (un-neutured) and female (un-spayed) ANY MALE dog over the age of 8 months old that is Intact (Not Neutered) is NOT ALLOWED to participate in group play and their Gingr animal profile must have the Individual play icon. ANY FEMALE dog over the age of 8 months old that is Intact (Not Spayed) is NOT ALLOWED to participate in group play and their Gingr animal profile must have the Individual play icon.

title: Daily Cleaning for East West Outside West and InBetween
content: Daily Cleaning for East West Outside West and InBetween Daily Cleaning for East, West, Outside West, and In-Between Operating Procedure Check the occupied runs for overlaps, dogs departing and arriving. Bring all dogs to a holding area. Let the Manager on Duty know if the dog needs a clean-up bath, especially if they are scheduled to go home. Remove all beds, bowls, toys, etc., from the floor. (all customer belongings should be labeled so they go back to the correct dog. If it is not labeled, please do so.) If anything is dirty, wet, or smelly; bring it to the laundry room (make sure to log any customer belongings on the guest laundry sheet). All items must be returned to the customer clean. Scoop any spilled food or solid waste. You must mark the run card for any elimination in their room and record food and water intake. Foam the main hallway floor, then walls, doors, floors and resting bench. Be sure to do the panel next to the door and the base of the bars and let sit for 10 minutes. Start the extra cleaning (see below). Rinse the walls first, top to bottom, rinse floor from front to back, top of resting bench, flip up and rinse bottom of resting bench. While rinsing, have the hose in one hand and a scrub brush in the other to tackle any remaining grime. Lastly, flush the drain towards the drain bucket until clean. Leave benches up to allow them to drip dry until you are done. Continue washing all bedrooms in this manner on both sides, from back to front On Mondays and more often as needed, empty drain buckets. Drain buckets are located in E 1, E 23, and W 1 and W 23. Lift the resting bench and lift the drain bucket out of the well to drip dry in the drain. Empty the drain buckets into a trash bag, clean and replace. Squeegee the doors; two swipes from top to bottom Squeegee the main hallway; two swipes angled towards the rooms Squeegee each bedroom from front to back, two swipes and gently put down the bench. Use fans to speed up drying if necessary. Put down clean water bowls in all occupied suites and fill using water jugs. If any dogs had belongings, put those back in with them now (give out our beds as needed to non chewers only). Bring all dogs back into their rooms. Extra Cleaning Refer to the posted checklist to see which 3 rooms will have the extra cleaning. Use an old broom and mop bucket filled with hot water, large and small hand brush, magic sponge, and cleaning cloths. Dip broom into mop bucket and scrub floors. Focus on edges, corners, and under the resting benches. All of the surfaces will already be soapy from foaming in the previous step. Rinse with one hand and use a hand brush with the other for bars, walls, and doorframes (especially the bases where grime sits. The brushes work great for breaking down the initial heavy grime while the magic sponge works well for the stubborn residue. Use the magic sponge on the glass doors inside and out. Squeegee the front and back of the 3 glass doors. Use foaming window cleaner and wipe the fronts and backs to make the glass shine. In addition to the insides of the suites, clean the outside just as well. Rinse the walls from top to bottom and front to back. Keep a sponge or brush on hand to remove any additional spots you’ve missed. Wipe down the metal frames with a rag, including the tops. Daily Outside West/In Between Cleaning: During the PM shift, clean any hallways that were used for daycare or boarding dogs during the day. These areas are cleaned the same as East and West wings. Move all to a holding area. Make sure reception is aware of their locations. Foam, Extra Clean, Rinse, and Squeegee. Put down water bowls and fill if the hallway will be occupied the following day (ex: don’t fill water bowls Friday night as areas will not be used for daycare on Saturday). Ask if you’re unsure.

title: Printing an ID Collar
content: Printing an ID Collar Printing an ID Collar Operating Procedure Important note: all room cards and ID collars should be printed in the morning, using the 'Reception Tasks Before Opening' procedure. This partucular procedure is only for the following cases: ID collar is damaged/missing and needs a replacement. Pet changed room - we'll need a new collar to reflect the new room. A pet shows up without a reservation. Printing an ID collar Note: only dogs (who are boarding) get ID collars. Navigate to the desired pet's reservation screen. Press the print button at the top right, and then click 'Print Labels'. This will give you access to a printing preview screen. (Note: if this does not show up, it is because pop-ups are disabled. You must enable popups in order for this screen to show up.) Press CTRL + P to print - ensure the destination is set to 'Petdetect Raster Printer' Under 'Copies' you must use the chart below to determine how long the collar will be. Smaller Breeds (<35 Lbs) Medium or Larger Breeds (~35-80 Lbs) (Most Common) Extra Large Breeds (>80 Lbs) 3 Labels Long 4 Labels Long 5 Labels Long Once the correct number of copies is entered and the correct printing destination is set, print out the label. Label should be printing now - if they are not, We have a switch (on the cash drawer) to swap between printing from the R1/R2 computer. Ensure that the light on the switch refects the computer you are currently using. Ensure there is a roll of label tape fed into the label printer (the colored side should be down - the roll of label tape fed into the machine should be the one on the left. There must be three rolls of label tape, side-by-side, in order for the label printer to work properly. Again - only the leftmost roll should be fed into the machine. If the label machine is stalling/not printing well, ensure the roll is aligned perfectly, with no additional slack. If the label machine is not cutting each collar well, wipe off the blade CAREFULLY with a disinfectant wipe. Remove all built-on gunk with the wipe and it should cut perfectly after . Place collar on dog if they are here, or if they have not come in, place the collar on the back wall behind the reception desk.

title: Long Term Stays
content: Long Term Stays Long Term Stays Operating Procedure If a pet stays for more than 2 weeks, we charge their card on file every week and apply a pre-payment to their reservation. We must let the client know of this, and we must keep a card on file for these situations. Please take down primary, secondary, and emergency contacts for these situations. Applying a pre-payment to a long-term reservation: Navigate to the desired reservation. Press the dollar sign icon on the top right of the screen to view the invoice. Press the green 'Apply Payment' button. Calculate the amount the customer owes up to this point: find the nightly lodging rate times the number of nights they have stayed thus far. Then add the activity package and pet care warranty, times the number of days they have stayed thus far. Add any other items the client should have paid for thus far. Then add tax (multiply this number by 1.0635. (CT sales tax)). This is the total amount you should charge for the pre-payment. Note: Make sure if there were any previous pre-payments, you are considering this when calculating the current pre-payment amount. Charge the calculated amount using the card on file. Note the file saying you have applied the pre-payment to the reservation, with the amount charged.

title: Late Checkout Fees
content: Late Checkout Fees Late Checkout Fees Policy & Operating Procedure Overnight Lodging Guests are allowed to depart before 11:00 AM with no additional fees. Lodging Guests that check out after 11:00 AM are assessed a late departure fee, which is the cost of one nightly lodging rate. This fee will automatically appear on the invoice during a departure after 11:00 AM. THE FRONT DESK IS RESPONSIBLE FOR: Waiving the late checkout fee if they have a bath or grooming service. If they have a bath or grooming service, late checkout is waived until 3:00 PM, or 5:00 PM if it is Sunday. Late checkout: Cost of one nightly lodging rate, will be charged: Normal: If has Bath or Groom on departure day: After 11:00AM After 3:00PM * 5:00PM on Sundays HOW TO WAIVE LATE CHECKOUT: Once item is in cart, start by seeing what the nightly lodging rate is. Click the arrow next to where it says "Reservation For [ Pet's Name ]" to locate this. If the departure day is a peak date, add both the nightly lodging rate listed and the peak charge, which is an additional $10 together to get a total late checkout fee. (Example: if the rate says $59.95, and it is a peak date, add $10 to get $69.95). Add an open line item: Use the 'Waive Late Checkout | Grooming Service' and enter in the lodging price you discovered in step 2. (Make sure it is a negative price) Add the discount to the cart, and proceed to the next steps of the checkout process.
