title: Gingr Dashboard Overview
content: Gingr Dashboard Overview Gingr Dashboard Overview The dashboard is the main control center. It displays pets expected to arrive and depart, pets currently checked in, and much more. This is a basic overview of the dashboard. There are four sections/tabs on the dashboard: ‘Expected Today’ section shows all reservations and appointments scheduled to come in today. ‘Going Home Today’ section shows all reservations and appointments scheduled to leave today. ‘Checked-In’ shows every single reservation or appointment checked in currently. ‘Requested’ shows any reservations requested online from a client. You can search: Animal name Last name Package (Gold, Silver, Bronze) to view all pets with a particular package. Boarding (Search to see only boarding pets) Daycare (Search to see only daycare pets) And more! Keep in mind you can only search for one term at a time. Press the columns at the top of list to sort in alphabetical or numerical order by Animal's Name, Owner's Name, Type of Reservation, Lodging Number, Services, Start Date, and End Date. Quick Check-In: This is a fast way to check in a daycare guest if they come in without a reservation. Please notify the customer of this so we can reserve a spot for them in the future (reservations are required for all types of services!). Press ‘Quick Check-In’ Button Select the desired type of daycare (‘Daycare | Full Day’ is default) Choose Animal(s) Press ‘Add!’ Lodging Calendar Button: Use this to navigate to the lodging calendar, which displays every guest's room number. If you checked out a pet and forgot what room the pet is in, navigate to the Lodging Calendar and do a ' CTRL + F ' search for the pet's name. Be sure to keep in mind last name as well! (We have lots of Bellas!) Paws Document Button: This is a Google Sheets document where we keep end of day, tour scheduling, price lists, and much more. Employee login feature (where your name is, on top right of screen): Ensure you are logged in whenever you are using the computer, and at the start of your shift. Use the quick login feature to log yourself in if you are not already logged in. At the end of your shift or when you are finished using the computer, press the logout button. Cart button: Just like shopping on Amazon, reservations and appointments are added to the shopping cart, and checked out from there. Please see the "Checking Out Pets" procedure for a detailed guide on how to check out clients. Text Message Feature on top right of Screen: Gingr has a built-in text messaging feature where we can easily send and receive messages from clients. The text message icon will have a red bubble with a number indicating there are unread messages. As soon as you click an unread message, it will be marked as read. Please respond to any unread text messages if applicable. Notification bell button: Shows system-generated notifications. Don't worry about this section - it just repeats things that are located and taken care of elsewhere in Gingr.

title: Adding New Client or Pet to Gingr
content: Adding New Client or Pet to Gingr Adding New Client or Pet to Gingr Operating Procdure This procedure will outline how to add a new client, or a new pet to an existing client file on Gingr. Creating a new client file On the left-hand side menu, navigate to ' Owners & Pets' > 'New Record'. Follow the company script to ensure all key data is filled out swiftly and accurately. ​​​​​​​Note: Gingr will come up with a notification if the email or phone number is already in use. In this case, stop creating a new file, and locate their existing file on Gingr. ​​​​​​​Once owner information is completed, press 'Continue to Next Step' to add the first pet. Use company script to fill out pet information accurately. If there are additional pets, press 'Save and Add Another Animal' and fill out all the required information. Once file is complete, press 'Save' at the bottom of page to save. Adding a pet to an existing file Navigate to the desired owner's file on Gingr. Press the pencil icon on the top right of the screen, then click 'Edit Owner'. Once in the editing owner screen, press 'Add Another Animal' at the top of the screen. Use company script to fill out pet information accurately. Once file is complete, press 'Save' at the bottom of page to save.

title: Gingr Email Confirmations and Reminders Overview
content: Gingr Email Confirmations and Reminders Overview Gingr - Email and Text Confirmations Overview This overview will describe confirmation and reminder communications with clients. To view emails that have been sent through Gingr, visit the ' Gingr - Viewing User History and Outgoing Email Log ' page on the knowledge base. Here is an example of a boarding confirmation email: Hello Joe Whitright, Thank you for booking with Paws Pet Resort & Spa! This is to confirm your boarding reservation for Honey arriving on October 23, 2023 at 7:00 am and staying with us until October 26, 2023 at 7:00 pm . *Please Send Paperwork Before Drop Off if Applicable* Required Paperwork: Dogs : Rabies Bordetella Distemper Dog License (paper copy) Negative Fecal Exam (from past year) Cats : Rabies Distemper We can now process your dog's fecal sample! Just drop by with the sample - we'll have the results back the next day! If any of the records listed below are expired, please send proof of up to date paperwork prior to your appointment. Honey's Records: Rabies October 16, 2026 at 12:00 am Bordetella October 18, 2024 at 12:00 am DHLPP August 29, 2023 at 12:00 am Dog License July 1, 2023 at 12:00 am Negative Fecal Test September 12, 2024 at 12:00 am Please ensure we have received all of your pet's updated records. If vaccinations are missing or expired, we ask that you send the documents to: Email: info@pawspet.com Any medications you would like us to administer must be in the original prescription bottle with your pet's name and dosage listed on it. All pets must be on an active flea and tick prevention program. All pets must be in good health and have not been ill with a communicable disease within the past 30 days. All bedding and bowls are provided. In the event you need to change your plans, we ask that you notify us two weeks prior to the reservation during peak times or three days prior during non-peak times. We look forward to seeing Honey during this upcoming stay. If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to call! Thank you and have a great day! Paws Pet Resort & Spa 312 East Johnson Avenue Cheshire, CT 06410 Phone: (203) 250-7297 Email: info@pawspet.com www.pawspet.com As you can see, it lists dates of stay, what vaccinations are needed, our contact information, and more. Automatic Confirmations sent to: Boarding reservations Grooming Appointments (also gets text confirmation) Automatic Reminders sent to: Boarding Reservations (email, sent 3 days prior to drop-off date) Grooming Appointments (text, sent 1 day prior to appointment) How to re-send a boarding confirmation email: Navigate to the boarding reservation. Press the email button. Press the 'Send Confirmation Email' button. Congrats! Email has been sent! Daycare: Daycare confirmation emails are not automatically sent out. If desired, to send one out manually, Navigate to the daycare reservation. Press the email button. Press the 'Send New Reservation Email' button. Congrats! Email has been sent!

title: Facility Calendar Overview
content: Facility Calendar Overview Facility Calendar Overview The facility calendar displays all grooming services, reservations, and services for a given day, week, or month. Key Points You can filter by specialist to see only grooming services for a particular specialist. All daycare reservations are colored green. All boarding reservations are colored blue. You can filter by day, week, or month.

title: Gingr Viewing User History and Outgoing Email Log
content: Gingr Viewing User History and Outgoing Email Log Gingr - Viewing User History and Outgoing Email Log Overview Gingr keeps track of everything. This will give you an overview on how to view user's actions, as well as viewing emails that were sent out from Gingr to clients. Please keep in mind that Gingr "batches" emails, so they will be sent once every ~1 to 5 minutes. If you do not see an outgoing email immediately, this is why. Viewing User History On the navigation bar on the left hand side of Gingr, navigate to 'Reports & More' > 'History'. If desired, you can search/filter by date, user, and/or action. Viewing Outgoing Email Log At the top of the history section, click the button titled 'Outgoing Email Log'. If desired, you can search/filter by email subject, date sent, and/or email delivery address. You can also view if the email was: Bounced: Was not delivered due to server or spam issues (very uncommon) Delivered: Email was successfully delivered to client. If an email was not delivered, the email address on file is likely to be incorrect. Please confirm this with the client. Opened: If the client opened the email. Clicked: If the client clicked on a link on an email, either to open our website or online portal.

title: Pulling Up Daycare List and Arrival and Departure Reports
content: Pulling Up Daycare List and Arrival and Departure Reports Pulling Up Daycare List and Arrival and Departure Reports Operating Procedure This procedure show you how to pull up daycare lists and boarding arrival and departure reports. Daycare Report: Navigate to 'Reports & More' > 'Reports' > 'Reservations By Day'. Select the desired date. In the 'Reservation Types' section, select only the daycare options. Press 'Generate Report'. "X" out of either the 'Check Ins' or 'Check Outs' section. Since daycares are for only one day, we must "X" out of one of them, otherwise the report will be duplicated. Then, press 'Print PDF' to print. Boarding Arrival Report and Departure Report: Navigate to 'Reports & More' > 'Reports' > 'Reservations By Day'. Select the desired date. In the 'Reservation Types' section, select only the boarding options. Press 'Generate Report'. This will generate both a 'Check Ins' and a 'Check Outs' section. To see only departures: "X" out of the 'Check Ins' section. To see only arrivals: "X" out of the 'Check Outs' section. Then, press 'Print PDF' to print.

title: Making Animal or Owner Notes
content: Making Animal or Owner Notes Making Animal or Owner Notes Operating Procedure There are two ways to make animal or owner notes in Gingr: Method One Navigate to the desired animal or owner profile. Open up the 'Employee Notes' tab. Write an in-depth, detailed note. Initial your name at the end of the note once you are done. Press 'Save Note' to save. Method Two Navigate to the desired animal or owner profile. Next to the animal's name, click the clipboard icon. This notes 'pop-up' screen allows you to switch between owner notes and animal notes easily. ​​​​​​​Warning: this method is easy to accidentally close out of, since you simply have to click anywhere outside of the notes section to close out of it and lose all of your data if you have not saved it yet. Write an in-depth, detailed note. Initial your name at the end of the note once you are done. Press 'Save Note' to save.

title: Deactivating a Pet
content: Deactivating a Pet Deactivating a Pet Operating Procedure When an animal unfortunately passes away, please deactivate them: Deactivating a pet's profile: Navigate to the correct pet's profile on Gingr. Press the pencil button, select 'Edit (pet's name)' At the bottom of the screen, press the button that says 'Archive Client (Deactivate)'. Press the 'Save' button at the bottom of the page. Otherwise, it will not be saved. Refresh the page to ensure changes were saved. Write an employee note in the owner's file about the pet passing away.

title: Daycare Punchcards Overview
content: Daycare Punchcards Overview Daycare Punchcards Overview Daycare punchcards are packages clients can buy in advance to save on the daily daycare rate. This is a quick overview on everything punchcards! How to check how many punches are left and the expiration date on a current punchcard: Navigate to the correct owner's account, find the 'Packages' section: This will list the name of the package, what the package is for, the expiration date, and remaining punches. How to purchase a new punchcard: Navigate directly to the cart (press the cart button on the top right of the screen). Select the owner. Press 'Browse Retail' Select the desired punchcard option. Please look at client's reservation history and ask them what package they want to ensure the correct punchcard option is selected. Take payment and check out the customer. Assigning 'Gets Punchcard' icon If a customer typically gets a punchcard, please add the 'Gets Punchcard' icon to their animal profile for future reference, making checkouts easier. Assign the 'Auto-renew Punchcard' icon if the client is a very regular customer and they want to get their punchcard auto-renewed without us asking them.

title: Pulling Up Service Reports
content: Pulling Up Service Reports Pulling Up Service Reports (Including Grooming and Activities) Operating Procedure This procedure will show you how to pull up grooming reports, activity package reports, and more. Navigate to 'Reports & More' > 'Reports' > 'Services By Date'. Select the desired date(s). In the ' Services ' section, select the desired service option(s). Press ' Scheduled Within Date Range ' - otherwise the report will show up incorrectly. If you are pulling up services from past dates, select 'Include Checked Out Reservations?' Press ' Generate Report! '. Then, press 'Print PDF' to print.

title: Icons Gingr
content: Icons Gingr Icons - Gingr Operating Procedure Icons are a way to view important information about a pet or client conveniently. Follow this overview on icons to learn how to add, delete, view, and understand icons on Gingr! What are 'Icons'? Icons display important information about a pet or customer with a quick glance. They can display what a pet typically gets, characteristics, type of play they are in, and much more! How to add Icons: Press the '+' button next to the animal or owner's name to add icons. This will bring up a menu of all available icons, select which Icon you would like to add. If necessary, write any notes in the 'Type comments here' field. You may also check off 'Create Employee Note?' if the information is important and would be a good fit to add to the client's notes. Press 'Add Icon' to save! How to delete Icons: Press the '+' button next to the animal or owner's name to get to the icon menu screen. Click on the icon you would like to delete. Press the 'Delete' button to save! Types of Icons: Icons that can be assigned include: Behavorial: Any important behavioral characteristics of a pet. Playtime type: Small, Medium, Big dog group, or Individual play. Typically gets: What a client typically gets in terms of activity package, room type, and more. Gender neutral name: If a pet has a gender neutral name, assign the Male or Female icon to clarify the pet's gender. (Ex. Charlie) Basic Icons Overview: These icons must be assigned to all our lodging guests. ROOM TYPE Standard Suite Mini Mansion Luxury Queen Suite Luxury King Suite PACKAGE TYPE Bronze Silver Gold Puppy TLC PLAY TYPE Small Dog Group Big Dog Group Individual/Custom Icons that are system-generated and automated include: Vaccination "Shield" Icon: a red shield icon will appear if records are needed, an orange shield will appear if a pet's records will expire within 30 days, and no shield icon will appear if the pet is all up-to-date. Appointment card: shows details about a pet's reservation, grooming cost history, and animal notes. Check-in questions Icon: Allows you to edit check in questions easily (only for boarding reservations) Dashboard details Icon: displays reservation notes, and some info on the animal and owner. Employee notes Icon: an easy way to access and add both Owner notes and Animal notes in one place. Owner Icons include: Card on file icon Punchcard icon (hover over this Icon to see remaining punches, and punchcard type!) On account balance Confirm or fix phone number Icon Info checked: Use this after we confirmed all contact information on file.

title: Editing or Entering Information on a Profile Including Feeding and Medication Instructions
content: Editing or Entering Information on a Profile Including Feeding and Medication Instructions Editing or Entering Information on a Profile Including Feeding and Medication Instructions Operating Procedure Anytime anything changes with a pet, it is vital to update the animal's profile to reflect the new information. Editing or Entering Information on a profile: Navigate to the pet's profile on Gingr. Press the pencil button, select either 'Edit Owner' or 'Edit (pet's name)', depending on what you want to edit. This screen will give you complete access to view, edit, or add any client information. Once you are done with what you needed to do, Press the 'Save' button at the bottom of the page. Otherwise, it will not be saved. ADDING OR EDITING FEEDING INFORMATION: Press the '+' button to add a new meal, and use the 'x' button to remove a meal. Simply deleting the text wont remove a meal - you need to press the 'x' button to completely delete the meal slot . If you need to change the feeding information that is already there, simply type over the existing text. Use caution and triple-check to make sure the feeding information is correct. ADDING OR EDITING MEDICATION INFORMATION: To add medications, press the plus button to add each medication, add quantity, unit and medication instructions. ) To delete medications, you need to press the 'x' button next to the medication slot. Use caution and triple-check to make sure the medication information is correct. You may also add specific date(s) if the medication is only for a certain time period. IF THERE ARE ANY QUESTIONS ON HOW TO DO THIS, ASK A SUPERVISOR. ACCURATE FEEDING AND MEDICATION INFORMATION IS OF UPMOST IMPORTANCE. Adding a Card on file (without a payment being processed): Navigate to the 'Edit Owner' screen. Locate the credit card section, and enter the credit card details. Press "Use this Card" AND THEN Press the Save button at the bottom of the page. If you do not press BOTH BUTTONS IN CORRECT ORDER, THE CREDIT CARD WILL NOT SAVE.

title: Making Recurring or Multiple Reservations or Appointments at Once
content: Making Recurring or Multiple Reservations or Appointments at Once Making Recurring or Multiple Reservations or Appointments at Once Operating Procedure This procedure will outline how to add recurring or multiple reservations or appointments at once. This is an in-depth overview that also includes how to comprehensively set up a reservation or appointment. To jump straight to the recurring or multiple reservation part, see the information below highlighted in blue . RESERVATIONS: Recurring Reservations (Only for Daycare): Navigate to the ' New Reservation ' screen (Navigate to the left-hand-side menu, 'Reservations' > 'New Reservation'.) Ensure pet(s)' name is selected under the 'Pet's' section. Ensure last name is correct and the correct pet(s) are selected. Select correct booking type under the 'Type' section. Select the first desired date . To add recurring dates: Press ‘Add Recurring Dates’ Button Select desired day(s) of week. If desired, select the frequency. NOTE: this will be rare you have to use this section. Select what date the recurring reservations stop. Press ‘Add Dates’. Once all details are entered, press ' Save ' at the bottom of the screen. It will display a notice saying, "A lodging must be selected for each date of this reservation." Proceed to press 'Override & Create,' as we do not reserve rooms for daycare reservations in advance. Making multiple reservations at once (Daycare or Boarding) Navigate to the ' New Reservation ' screen (Navigate to the left-hand-side menu, 'Reservations' > 'New Reservation'.) Ensure pet(s)' name is selected under the 'Pet's' section. Ensure last name is correct and the correct pet(s) are selected. Select correct booking type under the 'Type' section. Select the first desired date(s) . Press the 'Add Another Reservation' button and enter date(s). Add on any desired services and/or activities. Note: if there are different services on each reservation, make them separately to ensure each reservation is correct. Proceed to finalize reservation Boarding: assign room, write any notes, and take the $50 deposits (one per reservation). Daycare: do not assign room as usual, and write any notes Once all details are entered, press ' Save ' at the bottom of the screen. APPOINTMENTS: Navigate to the ' New Appointment ' screen (Navigate to the left-hand-side menu, 'Reservations' > 'New Appointment'.) Add pet(s)'s name under the 'Select Pets' section. Verify last name is correct. Under 'Service Category', select the only option available, 'Grooming' Under 'Appointment Type', select desired service. Under 'Specialist', select: For baths or nailtrims: always select 'Paws Bather'. For full service groom, select the appropriate full service groomer. The date field will autopopulate with the next available opening. Select the desired date (if a date is "grayed out" it is unavailable. For nail trims, after the date is selected, select only the drop off time and skip to step 8. Under 'Appointment Time', select the desired time. Green next to a time means it is available , and red means the time is unavailable. Note: if a client desires a time and it is not available (red), select the next closest time option and write the actual time in the notes. Let the client know the computer shows we only have a certain time available, but it is actually ok to come in at their desired time. The client will get a text and email confirmation with the date and time selected, so we want to make sure the customer is aware of this. If desired, add any service options under the 'Appointment options' section. Write any notes under the 'Notes' section. To add recurring or additional appointments, ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Press the 'Other Dates' button at the bottom of the screen, and enter either the desired recurring dates or the desired specific dates and press save. Press 'Create Appointment' once all details are finalized. ​​​​​​​ Note: Customer will promptly get email and text confirmation of the appointments with the dates and times. Please ensure the dates and times are correct before pressing 'Create Appointment'.

title: Signs of Bloat
content: Signs of Bloat Bloat Wellness Training Bloat is a very serious health risk for dogs. Bloating of a dog’s stomach is usually related to swallowed air (although food and fluid can be present). It usually happens when there is an abnormal accumulation of air, fluid, and/or foam in the stomach. Stress can be a significant contributing factor as well. As the stomach swells, it can rotate, causing the fixed attachments between the esophagus and upper intestine to twist. The twisting stomach traps air, food, and water in the stomach. The bloated stomach obstructs veins in the abdomen, leading to low blood pressure, shock, and damage to internal organs. This combined effect can lead to the death of a dog. Most Common Symptoms of Bloat: Attempts to vomit unsuccessfully, every 5-30 minutes. This is one of the most common signs Frequently “asking” to go outside to eliminate, significantly more often than normal Significant anxiety or restlessness “Hunched up” or “roached up” appearance Bloated abdomen that feels tight (like a drum) Potential Causes of Bloat High degree of stress Activities that result in gulping a large amount of air Food bowl elevated too high Rapid eating Eating fatty food(s) Drinking too much water too quickly Heredity Too much exercise before and especially after eating Disposition to bloat due to breed, heredity, temperament, or other contributing factors If you see any signs or signals that cause you to be concerned that a dog is experiencing bloat, retrieve a bottle of Gas-X from the meds cabinet. Give the dog 1 tablespoon of the gas-reducing medicine. Immediately call the manager or owner that is scheduled to be “on call” for emergencies to determine if and how the dog will be transported to a veterinarian.

title: Acute Colitis in Dogs
content: Acute Colitis in Dogs What You Need to Know About Acute Colitis Reference Material What is colitis? Colitis is a medical term that simply means inflammation of the colon. In dogs, this most commonly results in loose stool or diarrhea that may have mucus or fresh (red) blood. Affected dogs will usually defecate more frequently, and may strain as they defecate, or even attempt to defecate without producing any stool. Sometimes colitis is mistaken for constipation when dogs are straining but not defecating. Colitis may be chronic (lasting several days or weeks, or recurrent) or acute (sudden onset with a short duration). What causes acute colitis? Colitis is a common disease in dogs that can be caused by several factors. Excitement and stress are factors when it comes to acute colitis being observed in a pet care facility. Traveling, new situations and settings and being around new dogs are all contributors to canines. Another source of acute colitis is diet, whether it's a sudden change in food, water, overeating, or raiding the garbage. Acute colitis can also be brought on by parasitic infections. It typically takes several days to weeks from the time of contact for diarrhea to occur. Bacterial and viral infections can also be a cause, though less likely. How can you tell if a dog is affected? A dog with acute colitis typically has a good appetite, normal energy, and does not lose weight. Certain breeds including German Shepherds, Labrador retrievers, Irish Setters, Yorkshire terriers and miniature Schnauzers, among others, as well as nervous or excitable individual dogs, can be predisposed to developing diarrhea. Additionally, dogs have been with their owners for an extended period (as during COVID) may be more susceptible to colitis. In a pet care facility environment, it's important to identify individuals who may be at higher risk if they develop diarrhea. These include young puppies and kittens, debilitated pets or those with chronic medical conditions, very old pets, and very small dogs with profuse diarrhea. Other concerning factors include the presence of dark, tar-like stool, stool that looks like "raspberry jam," or a pet that is lethargic or declining. Any of these factors individually or in combination should be triggers to seek veterinary advice. How to manage acute colitis Fortunately, most cases of acute colitis resolve quickly with treatment. • Begin an immediate fast for 24-48 hours and keep water available. • Administer an over-the-counter supplement for diarrhea, such as Diagel or Pro-pectalin, every 12 hours for 1-3 doses. • Break the fast with a highly digestible diet formulated with a small amount of fermentable fiber, fed as small meals more frequently. Canned foods like Hills ID, Royal Canin GI, or Purina EN are good choices. • A typical regimen for a 50-pound dog (after fasting 24+ hours) would be 1/4 cup bland diet for the first meal followed by 1/4 cup of bland diet three times daily for the next 24 hours, then 1/4 cup of bland diet plus 1/4 cup of their typical diet twice daily for the next 24 hours, then a return to normal meals. • Probiotics such as Synacore, FortiFlora, and Proviable DC can be added to the food once or twice daily according to body weight for 3-5 days to help resolve diarrhea. • Early studies are looking at a possible role of polyphenols (like rutin, quercetin, and resveratrol) as beneficial supplements to heal the inflamed colon. • Stressed or nervous dogs may benefit from an over-the-counter anti-anxiety supplement, given with their guardian's permission, as either a diarrhea preventative or an addition once the diarrhea has resolved. These include CBD products, L-theanine, colostrum, hydrolyzed milk proteins, herbal formulas, and rescue remedy (applied directly to the inner eat or drops put in drinking water). Unfortunately, many of these products take several days to weeks of administration to produce a calming effect. • Young dogs with acute colitis should be evaluated for parasites and their veterinary record should be checked to determine the date of their most recent fecal exam and/or de-worming. Once a pet is back on a regular diet, the amount of food and the addition of any treats should be carefully evaluated. Pet parents often instruct lodging facilities to feed their pets more than they eat at home, either from concern that they don't want their pets to be hungry, or sometimes from a lack of knowledge of how much their dog or cat actually eats. A pet that overeats for a day or two will often develop diarrhea simply from the excessive amount of food being fed. How long will it take for affected dogs to return to normal? Typical acute colitis should resolve in 1-3 days. If a dog continues to have diarrhea that is not resolving, or if the diarrhea is worsening, veterinary care should be obtained. Sometimes a pet will have diarrhea upon returning home, even though the stools were completely normal while lodging. This can happen with a diet change, with the excitement of seeing their "people" again, or with over-zealous feeding of treats after being reunited. A fast of 12-24 hours, followed by small meals of a highly digestible food, usually is sufficient to resolve these situations.

title: Individual Custom Playtimes
content: Individual Custom Playtimes Individual / Custom Playtimes Operating Procedure During these play sessions, we ask that you engage with the dogs. At Paws we pride ourselves with offering the best care for our pet parents and their four-legged family members. A high standard and quality of play is required during these activities. The following are guidelines for appropriate behavior while conducting an individual playtime. If the dog is scheduled to depart early we do their playtime before the others. If a dog has multiple play times we try to space them out as much as possible, within reason. Do custom plays outside so the dog can get exercise. In the event of inclement weather (freezing, icy, thunderstorm) you may bring the dog outside to do their business then return to their suite, playgym, or lux hallway (if empty) to play with them. Start a timer for 15 minutes and record the time the playtime is started. Focus on the dog during the play time! Try to get the dog excited and playful if possible. If the dog does not want to play with you, you can pet them, talk to them, and/or walk around with them. Our guests deserve your undivided attention for a full 15 minutes. Observe the dog during your time with them, completing a wellness check. If there is food in their bowls, try hand feeding them to encourage them to finish. If you note there are any activities the dog especially loves doing, such as chasing a ball, belly rubs, or cuddling, write a note on their room cards and let the front desk know so they can make a note of it. Keep track of the pet using the bathroom, and record it on their room card once you bring them in. When you are done with the play time return the dog to their suite. Top off their water and remove empty bowls. Make note on their room card if they went to the bathroom or finished their food. At the end of your shift, fill out the Playlist with your times and tell shift lead/supervisor if a dog hasn't come in, left early, etc.

title: Pack Pro Training Reminders
content: Pack Pro Training Reminders Pack Pro Training Reminders Operating Policies New employees of Paws Pet Resort & Spa are provided access to PackPro's full video training curriculum and associated workbook. Key points of that education program are summarized below. Key Terms: DAYCARE: Daycare is a group of dogs socializing off leash, under the supervision of a handler. It is a privilege for well behaved, socially appropriate dogs . Daycare is an environment for social dogs to gather and play. Group daycare IS NOT an environment for unsocialized or aggressive dogs to learn appropriate social skills. NEUTRAL ZONE: An area in daycare that the handler determines temporarily or permanently dogs will not enter. DESENSITIZING: To prevent an emotional response in a dog (such as fear, anxiety, nervousness) to a training tool or training concept. Desensitization is the process of exposing the animal to a stimulus beginning at a very low intensity. LURING: Luring is when you guide your dog by holding a treat in front of their nose. The most effective way to use luring is to use the food lure to steer the dog into the desired position for the first few attempts, then transition the luring motion into a hand signal, and then add a verbal cue. COUNTER CONDITIONING: The conditioning of an unwanted behavior or response to a stimulus into a wanted behavior or response by the association of positive actions with the stimulus. Counter conditioning and desensitization need to be used together to be effective and are often used to change unwanted behavior in dogs. OVERSTIMULATION: Overstimulation is when a dog is mentally stimulated excessively, causing clouded thinking and behavior that the dog would ordinarily not do. Dogs that enter an overstimulated state of mind can make dangerous decisions in a group of dogs. It’s also very challenging for a dog to learn anything while they are in this state of mind. It can create behaviors such as: Spinning in circles Running around uncontrollably Being easily distracted Excessive panting (but it’s not that hot) Chewing unusual items Nipping or biting Jumping, leaping or lunging Barking and snarling. Key Skills You Must Execute to Properly Manage Group Play: Entering Play Group - stand tall and walk confidently. Body Blocking - DON'T: Use your hands to push dogs Move quickly Swing or kick your legs towards any dog Get frustrated or emotional Use correct Verbal Commands with Hand Signals Sit Down Off Out Come Here Wait Place That's Enough Use correct Tools in the proper manner Slip Leads Head Halter Slip Lead Kibble Treats Crates Prevent Fights through: Properly managing how dogs enter a pack of dogs Proper behavior corrections Preventing Over Arousal during play Teaching dogs basic skills Basic recall Group Sit Wait at the gate Stay out of my bubble Moving Groups Managing Unwanted Behaviors Identifying Proper Communication with other team members

title: Printing Playlist and Assigning Play Sessions
content: Printing Playlist and Assigning Play Sessions Printing Playlist and Assigning Play Sessions Operating Procedure This procedure will ensure all pet's playtimes are done accurately and efficeintly. Printing the Playlist: Please read and follow these steps carefully. The first part of the playlist is the daycare list. To print this, Navigate to Reports and More > Reports. Navigate to “Reservations by Date.” Put the date to today. Select only the daycare reservation types. Click “generate report”. Then, hit the “X” on the right hand side of “Check Outs” section - we don't need this, as it will duplicate the report. Then, hit the arrow on the "Check Ins" section to open it, and press “Animal” to sort by alphabetical order by animal’s first name. Then, press print, and you are good to go! The second part of the playlist is printing the boarding activities section. Navigate to Reports and More > Reports. Navigate to “Services by Date.” Next, make sure the date is correct. Make sure “additional service” is selected. Under the "Services" section, press the select all button. Delete the following: All the Pet Care Warranty selections OPG Fecal Testing Nail Trim Premium Bath Basic Bath Full groom with Haircut DO NOT DELETE ANYTHING ELSE! Next, make sure you select “Scheduled Within Date Range”. This is very important to make sure the activities show up correctly! Click generate report, and press print - do not filter in any order when doing this! The playlist is now printed. Marking Up the Playlist and Creating Lists for Team Members Assigning Play Sessions: Print the activity schedule and the day care report for the day. This must be done by 9:00AM. Using different colored markers, assign the groups. Using 4 separate colors, assign dogs to Big Dog/Small Dog groups Write lists with dogs names and room numbers for each group to hand out to staff at each group time. If a dog is coming in late and doesn't make it into their group play, we will do a custom play time instead. Put a yellow dot next to their name. Assigning Individual (Custom) Play Sessions: Using a yellow marker, make a dot next to all of the dogs that will have a custom play time. If a dog is scheduled to leave in the morning, make a note to do their playtime first. Notes and Exceptions for Assigning Play Sessions: Having a larger big dog group in the morning will often make the second group more manageable Dogs leaving today should go to the first group of their size Dogs arriving today should go to the last group of their size

title: Group Playtimes
content: Group Playtimes Group Playtimes Operating Procedure Before beginning any playgroup sessions: If Group is indoors; Make a clean mop bucket (256) with a new mop head and put it in one of the 3 rooms in the playgym. Get three water bowls for each play group (usually 12 total), fill with water, and place over the drain in the play room or outside. Water bowls must be switched out or cleaned with each play group. Ensure foldable fences are set up around the doors to ensure there is a double layer of entry, making it easier to bring dogs in and out of the group. Inspect areas for unsafe conditions, broken fence, gates, choking hazards, as well as any toys, food, etc. Start the Play School session outside in the yards to allow everyone to do their business. If the weather permits, they can remain outside on the green, otherwise move inside. During playgroup sessions: Follow the methods and strategies used by PackPro - see "Managing Group Play Sessions" procedure. Rinse and refill all water bowls every half hour to keep them fresh and clean Pick up any stools as soon as possible (ensure any contact with other dogs is prevented) Mop areas that were picked up (wring mop to remove excess water) Mop all urine as soon as possible so no dogs can track it around or step in it Keep the floor as dry as possible to avoid slipping. Using a squeegee is helpful! Make note of any incident in the incidents section of the client record of all dogs involved. Do not let dogs chew on things they shouldn’t, eat rocks, etc. After playgroup sessions: When bringing in dogs from playgroup, follow the ID collars of the boarding dogs, and either print out the daycare list or search where the dogs are using Gingr on your cell phone’s browser. Empty water bowls, bring to kitchen and wash them Empty scooper and wash off Bring mop bucket to laundry room, empty and rinse bucket, put mop head in washer Make sure all daycare dogs have water in their bedrooms when you are putting them back. If they have empty bowls, remove them now and mark the cards. Cleaning the Yards after Sessions: Sanitize with 256 both indoors & all outside yards – this should be done every day. Patios with concrete should not be cleaned during freezing temps. Empty the poop buckets from the play gym or greenyard and empty and refill scoop water buckets with foamer. Windex windows and clean off window sills and any surface that may collect dust or dirt. Clean out the gym drain bucket Monday & Thursday (twice per week).

title: Moving Dog to Individual Play
content: Moving Dog to Individual Play Moving Dog to Individual Play Operating Procedure IF a dog displays behavior NOT SUITABLE FOR GROUP PLAY during a group play session, immediately: Update the playlist to move the dog from Group to Private activities for the remainder of the day. Open the Guest's profile in Gingr. Remove the group play icon, and assign the individual play icon on their account. Make a note (or incident report if serious) on the animal's profile about exactly what behavior was observed, and why the dog is no longer suitable for group play. Notify the Front Desk staff to change all future activities on the dog's reservation to individual play. Also ask the Front Desk to check to see if the dog has any future reservations scheduled. If so the activities for all future reservations should also be modified. Front desk or supervisor must call the client to inform the client in a non-alarming manner. After confirming the future activities on the dog's reservation have been changed to individual play, write on the pet's run card to ensure they are not taken out to group again.

title: Evaluating Dogs for Group Play Evaluations
content: Evaluating Dogs for Group Play Evaluations Evaluating Dogs for Group Play (Evaluations) Operating Procedure If a pet parent wants their dog to play with other dogs, we will start by conducting an evaluation to be sure he or she will enjoy the group play experience. Only staff trained for Group Play should conduct evaluations. Take the dog out to the play yard and spend a few minutes getting to know the dog, letting the dog explore the play yard and get comfortable with his surroundings and you. If and when the dog seems comfortable and relaxed, introduce another dog with calm temperament and of similar size. Let them first meet through the gate then on a leash. If all goes well you can let them off the leash to interact. Supervise closely, watching for any signs of aggression or fear. If all goes well, bring out another dog that might be a little more playful than the first and see how they interact. If everyone is getting along and showing no signs of fear or aggression, you can slowly introduce the dog to the rest of the group. Notes must be made in the new dog’s client file regarding who did the evaluation, what dogs it was done with and how they did during the evaluation and during group play. Additional notes can be made as the dog progresses and feels more comfortable. Add a 'B', 'M', 'S', or 'I' icon to their Gingr file for future reference of what playtime they belong to. As part of a pet's first day, a midday call to the owner must be made and the rest of the first day checklist must be completed. Click here to view the first day checklist.

title: Managing Group Play Sessions
content: Managing Group Play Sessions Managing Group Play Sessions Operating Procedure Group play can be a great way for dogs to become socialized in a pack environment. However, it’s not for all dogs, which is why as an activities team member you will be tasked with monitoring and managing these group play sessions, ensuring all dogs are safely playing. It is important to establish your leadership role and maintain a safe and playful environment. The following are guidelines for effectively interacting with the pack while conducting a play session. Leadership Productive pack management starts with great leadership, which can be established in many ways. The following are some appropriate and effective ways to do so. Appropriate ways to establish a leadership role: When in play groups, a six-foot leash needs to be carried by the group leader at all times. This tool can be used to establish a bond with any dog in the play yard through leash work. It can be especially effective with members of the pack that display excessive energy and/or a lack of boundaries with the other pack members. Presenting yourself as the “alpha” to the pack is key to ensuring a safe and well-managed play group. Things like establishing eye contact and body posture (i.e., standing tall with an outward chest) project confidence and are great ways to achieve this presence. The following are ways to interact with the pack and it all starts when entering into the play yard. When walking into a play yard, ignore the pack members rushing toward you. To prevent dogs from jumping at your body, it is ok to slowly lift a knee in an upward motion to deter jumping at you. During this process, keep a calm composure and walk a couple laps around the field. If a dog nips at your fingers for attention and/or tries to get your attention by nudging at your hands, cross your arms just under your chest to help deter it. Walking the yard throughout the day in this manner projects confidence to the pack. It is important to constantly be moving and scanning the yard for high-energy dogs that you can interact with, while instilling your leadership. Gate management is key to keeping the dogs safe during the loading and unloading process of groups. It is also a great way to establish a boundary with the pack and display leadership. Gate management is done by positioning yourself in front of the gate entry/exit point. You will need to establish a three-foot boundary between you and the pack. This can be done using the command “wait.” You can also slowly lean your knee forward toward the dog(s). You do this by placing your right or left foot on the ground three feet in front of you and leaning your knee toward the pack. Repeat this until you have successfully established the three-foot space. Novice activity leads can remain in front of the pack, establishing eye contact with pack members. You can also use the command “sit” and/or “wait” to establish more leadership/authority (when using verbal commands it’s important to not overly communicate, allow at least five second pauses between each command.) Intermediate activity leads can establish themselves in front of the gate with it partially open with your body still in position to block the area. Advanced activity leads can practice with the gate fully open, your body at the gates side not blocking the entry/exit. “Group sit” is another great activity to practice with the pack. Find an area of the yard where you can gain the attention of the surrounding dogs. Using hand signals and the command “sit,” see how many in the area will respond to the command. Continue to practice this throughout the day. Novice activity leads have the surrounding dogs sit for a minimum of two seconds. Intermediate activity leads have the surrounding dogs sit for three seconds Advanced sit for four seconds. “Follow the Leader.” This is a great way to distract when dogs are fixating on a particular area or dogs. It is also a great way to establish a leadership role by redirecting the pack to follow your lead. During this activity, repeat the command “let’s go” one to three times in an energized and elevated tone while walking to the opposite end of the yard. Most pack members will fall in behind you; however, if they do not, continue to practice this throughout the day.
